title: 108_hr1106
content:
The Act titled "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" before discussing the conveyance of facilities. The Secretary of the Interior is required to convey all US interests in the water distribution system to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho. If the conveyance is not completed by a certain date, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay. The Secretary will require the District to pay administrative costs for the conveyance and related activities. Additionally, the District must pay the net present value of remaining obligations or $280,000 to the United States. Amounts received will go into the Reclamation Fund. SEC. 5. TETON EXCHANGE WELLS.

In conveying the Teton Exchange Wells, the Secretary shall transfer Idaho Department of Water Resources permit number 22-7022 and all related equipment to the District. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions of this Act are met.

SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW

Before the conveyance, the Secretary will complete all required environmental reviews as outlined in the Memorandum of Agreement referenced in section 3(a).

SEC. 7. LIABILITY. Prior to conveyance, the Secretary must complete environmental reviews as per the Memorandum of Agreement. The United States will not be liable for damages post-conveyance, except for negligence prior to the transfer. No increase in liability beyond current provisions in title 28, United States Code. Water supply to District lands. The acreage eligible for water supply from the Minidoka Project and Teton Basin Projects in the District is increased to include all lands as of the enactment date. This increase does not affect existing water storage contracts or State water law. Additionally, drought management planning is addressed. Within 60 days of enactment, the Secretary will collaborate with stakeholders in the Henry's Fork watershed to start a drought management planning process for all water uses. A report with the final drought management plan must be submitted to Congress within 18 months. SEC. 10. EFFECT. This section clarifies that the Act does not affect the rights of any person or the water rights of the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes of the Fort Hall Reservation. Any conveyance under the Act will not impact existing contracts or state laws regarding water rights.
